normalised: Arre yaar, load shedding! It is that time again, isn't it? Just when you're settled down to watch your favourite episode of "Taarak Mehta Ka Ooltah Chashmah," BOOM! Darkness. In India, especially during the scorching summer months, load shedding becomes a regular guest, invited or not.

unnormalised: **Load Shedding: When the Lights Go Out (and Your Chai Gets Cold!)**
normalised: What exactly is this load shedding drama, you ask? Basically, it is a fancy term for a planned power outage. See, our electricity grid, especially in some states like Bihar and Uttar Pradesh, sometimes can't handle the peak demand. Everyone switches on their A C s, coolers, and T V s at the same time, and the grid goes thud. To prevent a complete blackout – picture a whole city going dark, like something out of a dramatic Bollywood film – the power company, like, say, the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL), deliberately cuts off power to certain areas for a certain period.

normalised: Think of it like this: imagine you're hosting a huge Diwali party, and suddenly fifty extra guests show up wanting biryani. You only have enough for the guests you invited, right? So, you strategically portion the food to make sure everyone gets something instead of running out completely. Load shedding is kinda the same – rationing power to keep the whole system from crashing.

Chai gets cold, the ceiling fan stops, and the inverter starts making that irritating buzzing sound.
